Machine Learning Abstraction

Model-Decision Fns: linear, polynomial, logistic, neural net... -Nearest Neighbours, Decision Trees -Features -Low vs. high capacity (affects overfitting, underfitting, inference)

Classifiers

Suppose we have Bayes Optimal Classifier r(x)r(x)r(x)﻿, that is r(x)r(x)r(x)﻿ will output the prediction y that minimizes Bayesian Risk R(r(x))R(r(x))R(r(x))﻿.

3 ways to build classifiers

  1. Generative Models(e.g. LDA)
    1. Assume sample points come from probability distributions, different for each class.
    1. Guess form of distributions
    1. For each class C, fit distribution parameters to class C points, giving f(X∣Y=C)f(X|Y=C)f(X∣Y=C)﻿
    1. For each class C, estimate P(Y=C)P(Y=C)P(Y=C)﻿
    1. Baye’s Theorem gives P(Y∣X)P(Y|X)P(Y∣X)﻿
    1. If 0-1 loss, pick class C that maximizes
      1. P(Y=C∣X=x)=f(X=x∣Y=C)P(Y=C)P(Y=C|X=x)=f(X=x|Y=C)P(Y=C)P(Y=C∣X=x)=f(X=x∣Y=C)P(Y=C)﻿
  1. Discriminative Models (e.g. logistic regression)
    1. Model P(Y∣X)P(Y|X)P(Y∣X)﻿ directly.
  1. Decision Boundary
    1. Model r(x)r(x)r(x)﻿ directly

ROC Curve (Receiver Operating Characteristics)

X axis - False Positive Rate (FP) - Predictor predicts + but actually is -

Y axis - Sensitivity / True Positive Rate (TP) - Predictor predicts + and right

1 - x ⇒ Specificity / True Negative Rate (TN) - Predictor predicts - and right

1 - y ⇒ False Negative Rate (FN) - Predictor predicts - but actually is +

We want to minimize x and (1-y)

An infinite vector, and Φ(x)⋅Φ(z)\Phi(x) \cdot \Phi(z)Φ(x)⋅Φ(z)﻿ is a series that converges to k(x,z)k(x,z)k(x,z)﻿

RBF Kernel Function:

Transformation of Space in finding weights

In lots of ML algorithms we want to find a decision function that usually took form of a geometric shape like hyperplane / isocontour / isosurface in the original data space (x-space). However, in doing the optimization we usually want to find a vector(point) of weight w⃗\vec{w}w﻿ in the w-spaace that represents the geometric shape in the x-space. Therefore we have implicitly performed a transformation of space from x-space to w-space

Transformation to w-space in perceptron algorithm

For the perceptron algorithm, the transformation is performed below:

x-spacew-space
decision boundry{z:w⋅z=0}\{z : w \cdot z = 0\}{z:w⋅z=0}﻿ All points that has inner product of 0 with www﻿w
dataxxx﻿{z:x⋅z=0}\{z : x \cdot z = 0\}{z:x⋅z=0}﻿ All points that has inner product of 0 with xxx﻿

Since we want to force inequality x⋅w≥0x \cdot w \ge 0x⋅w≥0﻿ (for yi=1y_i = 1yi​=1﻿, then

  1. in x-space, xxx﻿ points for yi=1y_i = 1yi​=1﻿ should be on the same side of {z:w⋅z=0}\{z : w \cdot z = 0\}{z:w⋅z=0}﻿ as www﻿
  1. in w-space, www﻿ should be on the same side of {z:w⋅z=0}\{ z : w \cdot z = 0\}{z:w⋅z=0}﻿ as xxx﻿ that have yi=1y_i=1yi​=1﻿

Quadratic Form

A way to visualize symmetric matrices. Shows how applying the matrix affects the length of a vector.

If a symmetric matrix is diagonal:

  1. eigenvectors are coordinate axes
  1. ellipsoids are axis-aligned

A symmetric matrix MMM﻿ is:

  1. Positive Definite (PD)
    1. if ∀w≠0,w⊤Mw>0\forall w \ne 0, w^{\top}Mw > 0∀w=0,w⊤Mw>0﻿
    1. or all eigenvalues positive
  1. Positive Semi-Definite (PSD)
    1. if ∀w,w⊤Mw≥0\forall w, w^{\top}Mw \ge 0∀w,w⊤Mw≥0﻿
    1. or all eigenvalues non-negative
  1. Indefinite
    1. if both positive eigenvalue and negative eigenvalue exists
  1. Invertible(non-singular)
    1. if has no eigenvalue of 0

By eigendecomposition, we see that any real symmetric matrix has:

Where Λ\LambdaΛ﻿ is a diagonal matrix containing the eigenvalues of AAA﻿ and VVV﻿ is a orthonormal matrix which each column is the eigenvector of AAA﻿.

Note that ∣∣A−1x∣∣=1 or x⊤A−2x=1||A^{-1}x|| = 1 \text{ or } x^{\top}A^{-2}x = 1∣∣A−1x∣∣=1 or x⊤A−2x=1﻿ will have ellipsoid with axes and radii specified by the eigenvector and eigenvalues.

γ\gammaγ﻿ and h(z)h(z)h(z)﻿ are independent since h(z)h(z)h(z)﻿ only depends on training data and γ\gammaγ﻿ only on label of z.

  1. For many distributions, variance→0 as n→∞variance \rightarrow 0 \text{ as } n \rightarrow \infinvariance→0 as n→∞﻿
  1. If hhh﻿ can fit ggg﻿ exactly, then bias→0 as n→∞bias \rightarrow 0 \text{ as } n \rightarrow \infinbias→0 as n→∞﻿
  1. Adding a good feature reduces bias; adding a bad feature rarely increases it.
  1. Adding a feature usually increases variance (added dimension).
  1. Noise in test set only affects Var(ϵ)Var(\epsilon)Var(ϵ)﻿
  1. Noise in training set only affects bias&Var(h)bias \& Var(h)bias&Var(h)﻿
  1. We can test learning algorithms by choosing ggg﻿ and making synthetic data

Feature Selection

We want to identify poorly predictive features and ignore them so that we can:

  1. enjoy better inference speed
  1. less variance

Best Subset Selection

Forward Stepwise Selection

  1. Start with null model (0 features)
  1. repeatedly add best feature until validation errors start increasing
    1. At each outer iteration, inner loop tries every feature and chooses the best by validation
  1. Requires training O(d2)O(d^2)O(d2)﻿ modules instead of O(2d)O(2^d)O(2d)﻿
  1. But
    1. won’t find the best 2-feature model if neither one of those features yields the best 1-feature model.

Backward stepwise selection

  1. Start with all d features
  1. repeatedly remove feature whose removal gives best reduction in validation error
  1. Also trains O(d2)O(d^2)O(d2)﻿ models
  1. Additional heuristic: only try to remove features with small weights
    1. Small relative to the variance of least-square regression
    1. Variance of least sqaure regression is proportional to σ2(X⊤X)−1\sigma^2 (X^{\top}X)^{-1}σ2(X⊤X)−1﻿
    1. z-score of weight wiw_iwi​﻿ is zi=wiσviz_i = \frac{w_i}{\sigma\sqrt{v_i}}zi​=σvi​​wi​​﻿ where viv_ivi​﻿ is the ith diagonal entry of (X⊤X)−1(X^{\top}X)^{-1}(X⊤X)−1﻿
    1. Small z-score hint that the “true” wiw_iwi​﻿ could be zero.

Kernel Trick

Kernel Trick is developed from the fact that in many algorithms,

  1. weights can be written as a linear combination of sample points
    1. Therefore we can write w=∑i=1naiXi=X⊤a,a∈Rnw = \sum_{i=1}^n a_i X_i = X^{\top} a, a \in \mathbb{R}^nw=∑i=1n​ai​Xi​=X⊤a,a∈Rn﻿
  1. we can use inner products of Φ(x)\Phi(x)Φ(x)﻿ only instead of directly computing Φ(x)\Phi(x)Φ(x)﻿.
    1. We will define the kernel function k(x,z)=Φ(x)⋅Φ(z)k(x,z) = \Phi(x) \cdot \Phi(z)k(x,z)=Φ(x)⋅Φ(z)﻿
    1. Note that we can use different kernel function can be substituted to use different kernels.
    1. The real magic happens when we can compute k(x,z)k(x,z)k(x,z)﻿ really quickly.

High-Dimensional Data

Distribution of random points

Suppose we have a random point p∼N(0,I)∈Rdp \sim N(0,I) \in \mathbb{R}^dp∼N(0,I)∈Rd﻿

The vast majority of the random points are at approximately the same distance from the mean, laying in a thin shell. (Think about chi-sqaure distribution)

Angles between random points

Therefore as d becomes larger, θ\thetaθ﻿ becomes more and more likely to be very close to 90 deg!

Learning Theory

Range Space(Set System) AAA﻿: a pair (P,H)(P,H)(P,H)﻿ where

PPP﻿ is the set of all possible test/training points

HHH﻿ is the set of hypotheses(ranges/classifiers), each hypothesis states which subset of P (h⊆Ph \sube Ph⊆P﻿) are in class CCC﻿

Examples of classifiers:

  1. Power set classifier: PPP﻿ is a set of kkk﻿ numbers, HHH﻿ is the power set of P, containing all 2k2^k2k﻿ subsets of PPP﻿
    1. This classifier cannot generalize at all because if given any subset of PPP﻿ as training data, it can fit a lot of classifiers and we wouldn’t know which classfier would be good generalization of the other data we haven’t seen unless we see the other data.
  1. Linear classifier: P=RdP = \mathbb{R}^dP=Rd﻿, HHH﻿ is the set of all halfspaces: {∀w,α,list of {x:w⋅x≥−α}}\{\forall w, \alpha, \text{list of }\{x: w \cdot x \ge -\alpha\}\}{∀w,α,list of {x:w⋅x≥−α}}﻿

A great question to ask about a certain class of hypotheses would be:

Let all training points and test points drawn independently from probability distribution DDD﻿ defined on domain PPP﻿, then

Suppose our hypothesis is h∈Hh \in Hh∈H﻿,

the risk / generalization error R(h)R(h)R(h)﻿ of hhh﻿, is the probability that hhh﻿ misclassifies a random point xxx﻿ drawn from DDD﻿ ⇒ average test error

the empirical risk / training error R^(h)\hat{R}(h)R^(h)﻿ is the percentage of training data points misclassified by hhh﻿

Hoeffding’s inequality tells us probability of bad estimate:

“How likely that a number drawn from a binomial distribution will be far from its mean”

So...we want to choose h^∈H\hat{h} \in Hh^∈H﻿ that minimizes R^(h^)\hat{R}(\hat{h})R^(h^)﻿, a technique called empirical risk minimization

however, its computationally infeasible to pick the best hypothesis ⇒ SVM find a linear classifier with zero training error when the training data is linearly separable, but when it isn’t SVM try to find a linear classifier with low training error, not minimum.

Dichotomies

A dichotomy of XXX﻿ is X∩hX \cap hX∩h﻿, where h∈Hh \in Hh∈H﻿

It picks out the training points that h predicts are in class C

Up to O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n)﻿ dichotomies. The more dichotomies, the more likely it is that one of them will get lucky and have misleading low empirical risk

Given Π\PiΠ﻿ dichotomies,

Therefore, the smaller we make Π\PiΠ﻿ and the bigger we make nnn﻿, the more accurate we can predict the risk based on the empirical risk

Suppose we chose h^\hat{h}h^﻿ as our hypothesis, then with probability ≥1−δ\ge 1 - \delta≥1−δ﻿,

Where

and h∗h^*h∗﻿ being the optimal hypothesis in the class HHH﻿

Therefore, with enough training data and a limit on the number of dichotomies, empirical risk minimization usually chooses a classifier close to the best one in the hypothesis class.

After choosing δ\deltaδ﻿ and ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿,

the sample complexity is the number of training points needed to achieve this ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿ with probability ≥1−δ\ge 1-\delta≥1−δ﻿:

Shatter Function

number of dichotomies: ΠH(X)=∣{X∩h:h∈H}∣∈[1,2n] where n=∣X∣\Pi_H(X) = |\{X \cap h: h \in H\}| \quad \in [1,2^{n}] \text{ where } n = |X|ΠH​(X)=∣{X∩h:h∈H}∣∈[1,2n] where n=∣X∣﻿

shatter function: ΠH(n)=max⁡∣X∣=n,X⊆PΠH(X)\Pi_H(n) = \max_{|X|=n, X \sube P} \Pi_H(X)ΠH​(n)=max∣X∣=n,X⊆P​ΠH​(X)﻿ ⇒ max number of dichotomies of any training set of size n

Its called a shatter function because HHH﻿ shatters aset XXX﻿ of n points if ΠH(X)=2n\Pi_H(X)=2^nΠH​(X)=2n﻿.

e.g. Linear classifiers in plane, HHH﻿ = set of all halfplanes, ΠH(3)=8\Pi_H(3)=8ΠH​(3)=8﻿

Fact: for all range spaces, either ΠH(n)\Pi_H(n)ΠH​(n)﻿ is O(np)O(n^p)O(np)﻿ or O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n)﻿

Cover’s theorem

linear classifiers in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd﻿ allow up to ΠH(n)=2∑i=0d(n−1i)\Pi_H(n)=2\sum_{i=0}^d {n-1 \choose i}ΠH​(n)=2∑i=0d​(in−1​)﻿ dichotomies of n points

For n≤d+1n \le d+1n≤d+1﻿, ΠH(n)=2n\Pi_H(n)=2^nΠH​(n)=2n﻿

For n≥d+1n \ge d+1n≥d+1﻿, ΠH(n)≤2(e(n−1)d)d⟸polynomial in n with exponent d\Pi_H(n) \le 2{e(n-1) \choose d}^d \quad \Longleftarrow \text{polynomial in n with exponent d}ΠH​(n)≤2(de(n−1)​)d⟸polynomial in n with exponent d﻿

Hard-Margin Support Vector Machine (Hard-Margin SVM)

The problem with perceptron algorihtm is that we can fit infinitely many hyperplanes to the data since it does not constrain the weight vector, just asking it to be correct on classifying data (it can fit training data 100% but it may not generalize well to validation or test set). This may lead to increased variane.

We will enforce the constraints:

Note that the RHS is a 1, and it is makes impossible for the weight vector www﻿ to get set to zero.

Therefore the optimization problem:

Its a quadratic program in d+1d+1d+1﻿ dimensions and nnn﻿ constraints, and has a unique solution (if points are linearly seperable).

The reason that we don’t want to use ∣∣w∣∣||w||∣∣w∣∣﻿ is because it is not smooth at w=0w=0w=0﻿, whereas ∣∣w∣∣2||w||^2∣∣w∣∣2﻿ is smooth everywhere, making it easier to optimize.

Soft-Margin SVM

Idea: Allow some points to violate the margin with slack variables ξi≥0\xi_i \ge 0ξi​≥0﻿.

Now we re-define the margin to be 1/∣∣w∣∣1/||w||1/∣∣w∣∣﻿, since the margin is no longer the distance from the decision boundary to the nearest sample point.

Therefore the optimization prblem:

C>0C>0C>0﻿ is a scalar regularization hyperparameter that trades off

small Cbig C
desiremaximize margin 1∣∣w∣∣\frac1{||w||}∣∣w∣∣1​﻿keep most slack variables zero or small
dangerunderfittingoverfitting
outliersless sensitivevery sensitive
boundarymore “flat”more sinuous

Gaussian Discriminant Analysis(GDA)

Isotropic Gaussians

Anisotropic Gaussians(Different variances along different directions)

Where Σ\SigmaΣ﻿ is d×dd \times dd×d﻿ Semi Positive Definite Covariance Matrix.

Semi Positive Definite: ∀w⃗,w⃗⊤Σw⃗≥0\forall \vec{w}, \vec{w}^{\top}\Sigma \vec{w} \ge 0∀w,w⊤Σw≥0﻿

And Σ−1\Sigma^{-1}Σ−1﻿ is d×dd \times dd×d﻿ SPD precision matrix.

Let q(x)=(x−μ)⊤Σ−1(x−μ)q(x) = (x-\mu)^{\top}\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu)q(x)=(x−μ)⊤Σ−1(x−μ)﻿, therefore f(x)=n(q(x))f(x) = n(q(x))f(x)=n(q(x))﻿ where n(⋅)n(\cdot)n(⋅)﻿ is a sample, monotonic, convex function that is an exponential of the negative of its argument. n(⋅)n(\cdot)n(⋅)﻿ does not affect the isosurfaces.

q(x)q(x)q(x)﻿ is the squared distance from Σ−1/2x\Sigma^{-1/2}xΣ−1/2x﻿ to Σ−1/2μ\Sigma^{-1/2}\muΣ−1/2μ﻿.

d(x,μ)=∣∣Σ−1/2x−Σ−1/2μ∣∣=(x−μ)⊤Σ−1(x−μ)=q(x)d(x,\mu)=||\Sigma^{-1/2}x-\Sigma^{-1/2}\mu||=\sqrt{(x-\mu)^{\top}\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu)}=\sqrt{q(x)}d(x,μ)=∣∣Σ−1/2x−Σ−1/2μ∣∣=(x−μ)⊤Σ−1(x−μ)​=q(x)​﻿

Important fact: if you understands isosurface of quadratic form then you can understand isosurface of Gaussian, only difference is that the max isovalue is at the mean of the Gaussian.

Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA)

compute conditional mean μ^c\hat{\mu}_cμ^​c​﻿ and conditional variance σ^c2\hat{\sigma}_c^2σ^c2​﻿, Σc\Sigma_cΣc​﻿ of each class C seperately.

And estimate the priors π^c=ncn\hat{\pi}_c = \frac{n_c}{n}π^c​=nnc​​﻿ (number of points in class c divided by total number of sample points)

Note: If we had zero eigenvalues in the variance matrix, then the standard QDA doesn’t work. We can fix it by adding a regularization term λI\lambda IλI﻿ on the matrix Λ\LambdaΛ﻿, which Σ^c=VΛV⊤\hat{\Sigma}_c = V\Lambda V^{\top}Σ^c​=VΛV⊤﻿, and use this Σ~c=V(Λ+λI)V⊤\tilde{\Sigma}_c = V(\Lambda + \lambda I) V^{\top}Σ~c​=V(Λ+λI)V⊤﻿ term as our new covariance matrix. We want to keep the term λ\lambdaλ﻿ relatively small to not affect the covariance matrix too much.

Note: Posterior P(Y=C∣X=x)=s(Qc(x)−∑d≠cQd(x))P(Y=C|X=x) = s(Q_c(x) - \sum_{d \ne c} Q_d(x))P(Y=C∣X=x)=s(Qc​(x)−∑d=c​Qd​(x))﻿ where s(⋅)s(\cdot)s(⋅)﻿ is the sigmoid function.

Ridge Regression

(1) Linear Function + (A) Squared Loss + (d - a) L2 Penalized Mean Loss

    1. Always unique solution

After setting ∇J=0\nabla J = 0∇J=0﻿,

Bayesian Justification for Ridge Regression:

then

Maximize log posterior:

So therefore minimize ∣∣Xw−y∣∣2+λ∣∣w’∣∣2||Xw-y||^2+\lambda||w’||^2∣∣Xw−y∣∣2+λ∣∣w’∣∣2﻿

Lasso Regression

(1) Linear Function + (A) Squared Loss + (e - a) L1 Penalized Mean Loss

Similar to ridge regression, but has the advantage that it often naturally sets some of the weights to zero (not always zero, just due to the graphical property of L1 Loss the weights are more likley to rest on points of 0)

The isosurfaces of ∣∣w’∣∣1||w’||_1∣∣w’∣∣1​﻿ are cross-polytopes (we write w’w’w’﻿ because we don’t want to penalize α\alphaα﻿)

The unit cross-polytope is the convex hull (凸包 - 刚好包住所有点的塑胶膜) of all the positive and negative unit coordinate vectors.

Compare to ridge regression, the solution given by lasso is more likely to be sparse because the isosurfaces of the regularization term and the isosurfaces of squared distance is more likely to meet at the direction of the unit coordinate vectors.

Lasso can be reformulated as a quadratic problem, Subgradient descent and least-angle regression(LARS), forward stagewise algorithms can be used to solve for Lasso.

Decision Trees

Still widely used, fast, interpretable, invariant to scaling/translation, robust to irrelevant features ,and can achieve 100% training accuracy, but prune to overfitting. Random Forest and Adaboost is introduced to prevent some of the overfitting

  1. Cuts x-space into rectangular cells
  1. Works well with both categorical(split by subset) and quantitative(split by boundary) features
  1. Interpretable result
  1. Decision boundary can be arbitrarily complicated

Learning:

def GrowTree(S):
	if(training points in node have same class) or (node exceeds maximum depth):
		return most common class in node
	else:
		choose best splitting feature j and sppliting value (or subset) beta
		filter training points to the left split or right split
		return Node(
				j,
				beta,
				GrowTree(left training points),
				GrowTree(right training points)
		)

How to select best split:

  1. Try all splits
  1. Choose split that maximizes information gain H(S)−HafterH(S)-H_{after}H(S)−Hafter​﻿

Where H(S)H(S)H(S)﻿ is the entropy of an index set SSS﻿ ⇒ the average surprise

The suprise of YYY﻿ being in class C is −log2(pc)-log_2(p_c)−log2​(pc​)﻿

  1. event with probability gives us zero surprise
  1. event with probability gives us inifinite surprise

The entropy of an index set SSS﻿ is the average surprise

  1. If all points in S belong to the same class ⇒ H(S)=−1log⁡2(1)=0H(S)=-1\log_2(1)=0H(S)=−1log2​(1)=0﻿
  1. Half class C, half class D ⇒ H(S)=−0.5log⁡2(0.5)−0.5log⁡2(0.5)=1H(S)=-0.5\log_2(0.5)-0.5\log_2(0.5)=1H(S)=−0.5log2​(0.5)−0.5log2​(0.5)=1﻿
  1. n points, all different classes ⇒ H(S)=−log⁡21n=log⁡2(n)H(S)=-\log_2 \frac{1}{n} = \log_2(n)H(S)=−log2​n1​=log2​(n)﻿

Where HafterH_{after}Hafter​﻿ is the weighted average entropy after the split

Multivariate splits

Standard decision trees are fast because they only check one feature at each node. But if there are hundreds of features, it slows down classification a lot since in every node you need to look at lots of features at once.

Pruning

  1. Grow tree
  1. greedily remove each split whose removal improves validation performance
  1. More reliable than stopping early

Decision Tree Regression

  1. Uses the concept of decision tree
  1. Creates a piecewise constant regression function

Cost:

Where μs\mu_sμs​﻿ is the mean label yiy_iyi​﻿ for sample points i∈Si \in Si∈S﻿

Random Forests

Idea:

  1. At each treenode, only allowed to split on m features (out of d)
    1. not allowed to split on the other d-m features
    1. m≈dm \approx \sqrt{d}m≈d​﻿ great for classification, and m≈d/3m \approx d/3m≈d/3﻿ for regression
    1. mmm﻿ is a hyperparameter

Pros:

  1. Sometimes test error reduction up to 100x or 1000x of decision trees

Cons:

  1. Slow
  1. Loses interpretability

Variant: Multivariate split random forest

Neural Networks

Oh yes, please also check out my notes for Andrew Ng’s DL Specialization

Problem with perceptron: only linear combinations, cannot model a XOR gate

Idea 1: Feature Lifting

Idea 2: Activation Function (Used by NN!) ⇒ Added Non-linearity between the linear combinations, can be as simple as clamping the output

History chooses sigmoid, but now we can use tanh, relu, leaky relu, softmax, etc.

Therefore steps to train neural network

  1. Design architecture (# of hidden layers, activation function, etc.)
  1. Choose Cost Function (BCE Loss, Squared Loss, etc.)
  1. Choose Optimizer (Gradient Descent, Stochastic Gradient Descent, Mini-batch Gradient Descent, Momentum, RMSProp, Adam, AMSGrad, etc.)
  1. Training Loop
    1. Forward prop ⇒ back prop

Problem for Neural Net:

  1. Has a symmetry problem
    1. If weights are initialized to be zero, there’s no difference between one hidden unit and an other - they are computing the same thing
    1. Break symmetry by weight initialization
  1. Diminishing/Exploding Gradient ⇒ Gradient fail to pass through a network too deep / Gradient being too big
    1. Gradient Clipping(for exploding gradient)
    1. BCE loss for the last layer
    1. Skip connections
    1. Centering the hidden units
      1. replace sigmoids with tanh
    1. Whitening Training Data (to gain a great bowl shape in w-space)
    1. BatchNorm layer
  1. If dimension of data is big, then second-order optimization is not applicable
    1. Newton’s method required too much computation power for the Hessian
    1. Alternative - Stochastic Levenberg Marquardt: approximates a diagonal Hessian

To avoid overfitting:

  1. Random init weights
  1. Bagging
  1. L2 Regularization
  1. Dropout

For CNN, see my notes for Andrew Ng.

Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

A technique for dimensional reduction (subset of unsupervised learning)

Normalize the data? Sometimes yes, sometimes no If some features are much larger than others, they will tend to dominate the Euclidean distance. So if we have features in different units of measurement we should probably normalize. But if in the same unit of measurement, it depends on the context (usually shouldn’t)

Reason for PCA:

  1. Speed - Reducing number of dimensions makes some computations cheaper
  1. Variance Reduction - Remove irrelevant dimensions to reduce overfitting
    1. Like subset selection, but features are not axis-aligned
    1. instead linear combinations of input features
  1. Finding a small basis for representing maximum variations in complex things
  1. Minimizes the mean sqaured projection distance

Projection: Orthogonal projection of point xxx﻿ onto vector www﻿ is

We want to pick the best k directions, span{v1,v2,…,vk}span\{v_1,v_2,\dots,v_k\}span{v1​,v2​,…,vk​}﻿ to project our inputs onto.

The Singular Value Decomposition of X,

gives us the best basis to project onto.

Note: Here, U,VU,VU,V﻿ are orthonormal matrices with column vectors and Λ\LambdaΛ﻿ is a diagonal matrix with singular value σi\sigma_iσi​﻿s.

Columns of UUU﻿ are unit eigenvectors of XX⊤XX^{\top}XX⊤﻿, Columns of VVV﻿ (Rows of V⊤V^{\top}V⊤﻿) are eigenvectors of X⊤XX^{\top}XX⊤X﻿. And the singular value, σi\sigma_iσi​﻿s, are square root (σi=λi\sigma_i=\sqrt{\lambda_i}σi​=λi​​﻿) of eigenvalues of both XX⊤XX^{\top}XX⊤﻿ and X⊤XX^{\top}XX⊤X﻿.

K-Means Clustering

Normalize the data? Sometimes yes, sometimes no If some features are much larger than others, they will tend to dominate the Euclidean distance. So if we have features in different units of measurement we should probably normalize. But if in the same unit of measurement, it depends on the context (usually shouldn’t)

Partition n points into k disjoint clusters

Assign each input point XiX_iXi​﻿ a cluster label yi∈[1,k]y_i \in [1,k]yi​∈[1,k]﻿

Cluster iii﻿ will have mean μi=1ni∑yj=iXj\mu_i = \frac1{n_i} \sum_{y_j=i} X_jμi​=ni​1​∑yj​=i​Xj​﻿ given nin_ini​﻿ points in cluster iii﻿.

Find yyy﻿ that minimizes ∑i=1k∑yj=i∣∣Xj−μi∣∣2\sum_{i=1}^k \sum_{y_j=i} ||X_j - \mu_i||^2∑i=1k​∑yj​=i​∣∣Xj​−μi​∣∣2﻿

NP-hard, try every partition ⇒ O(nkn)O(nk^n)O(nkn)﻿

Lloyd’s Algorithm (Finds a Local Minimum on the Cost Function)

First, start with either

  1. Forgy method: choose k random sample points to be initial μi\mu_iμi​﻿ ⇒ goto 2
  1. Random partition: randomly assign each sample point to a cluster ⇒ goto 1
  1. k-means ++: Like Forgy, but biased distribution so that each center is chosen with a preference for points far from previous centers.

Alternates between

  1. fixing yjy_jyj​﻿, updating μi\mu_iμi​﻿
    1. Optimal μi\mu_iμi​﻿ is the mean of points in cluster i by calculus
  1. fixing μi\mu_iμi​﻿, updating yjy_jyj​﻿
    1. Optimial yyy﻿ assigns each point XjX_jXj​﻿ to the closest center μi\mu_iμi​﻿

k-Medoids Clustering

Generalizes k-means clustering beyond Euclidean distance

Specify a distance(dissimilarity) function between points d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y)﻿

Replace mean with medoid(中心点), the sample point that minimizes total distance to other points in the same cluster.

Hierarchical Clustering

  1. Creates a tree
    1. Every subtree is a cluster

Two techniques

  1. agglomerative clustering (Greedy agglomerative algorithm naturally takes O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)﻿ time)
    1. From bottom up
    1. Start with each point being a cluster, repeatedly fuse pairs
  1. divisive clustering
    1. From top down
    1. Start with all points in the same cluster, repeatedly split it.

We need a distance function between clusters A,B

  1. complete linkage d(A,B)=max⁡{d(w,x):w∈A,x∈B}d(A,B)=\max\{d(w,x): w \in A, x \in B\}d(A,B)=max{d(w,x):w∈A,x∈B}﻿
  1. single linkage d(A,B)=min⁡{d(w,x):w∈A,x∈B}d(A,B)=\min\{d(w,x): w \in A, x \in B\}d(A,B)=min{d(w,x):w∈A,x∈B}﻿
  1. average linkage d(A,B)=1∣A∣∣B∣∑w∈A∑x∈Bd(w,x)d(A,B)=\frac{1}{|A||B|}\sum_{w \in A}\sum_{x \in B}d(w,x)d(A,B)=∣A∣∣B∣1​∑w∈A​∑x∈B​d(w,x)﻿
  1. centroid linkage d(A,B)=d(μA,μB)d(A,B) = d(\mu_A, \mu_B)d(A,B)=d(μA​,μB​)﻿ where μs\mu_sμs​﻿ is mean of SSS﻿

Random Projection

An alternative to PCA as preprocess for clustering, classification, regression

  1. Sometimes preserves distance better than PCA
    1. best when projecting a very high-dim space to a medium-dim space

We pick a small ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿, a small δ\deltaδ﻿, and a random subspace S⊂RdS \sub \mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd﻿ of dimension k=⌈2ln⁡(1/δ)ϵ2/2−ϵ3/3⌉k = \lceil \frac{2\ln(1/\delta)}{\epsilon^2/2-\epsilon^3/3} \rceilk=⌈ϵ2/2−ϵ3/32ln(1/δ)​⌉﻿

Subspace SSS﻿ can be obtained by choosing kkk﻿ arbitrary directions and use Gram-Schmidt to orthonormalize them.

We will project any point qqq﻿ to q^\hat{q}q^​﻿, and q^=dk⋅projS(q)\hat{q} = \sqrt{\frac{d}{k}} \cdot proj_{S}(q)q^​=kd​​⋅projS​(q)﻿

The constant dk\sqrt{\frac{d}{k}}kd​​﻿ is used to preserve distance

k-Nearest Neighbour

As k becomes larger, the decision boundary is smoother.

Depending on dimension,

  1. 2-5 dimensions: Vornoni Diargrams
  1. Medium dimension (up to ~30): k-d trees
  1. Large dim
    1. exhaustive k-NN with PCA or random projection
    1. locality sensitive hashing

Exhaustive k-NN Algorithm:

Given query point q:

  1. Scan through all n sampple points, computing (squared) distance to q
  1. Maintain a max-heap with the k-shortest distances so far
    1. When we encounter a sample point closer to q than the point at the top of the heap, simply remove the top of the heap and insert the new pint.

Time to train: O(0)O(0)O(0)﻿

Time to query: O(nd+nlog⁡(k))O(nd+n\log(k))O(nd+nlog(k))﻿, expected Θ(nd+klog⁡(n)log⁡(k))\Theta(nd+k \log(n) \log(k))Θ(nd+klog(n)log(k))﻿ if random point order

Voroni Diagrams

Let XXX﻿ be a point set, the Voroni cell(always a convex polyhedron or polytope) of w∈Xw \in Xw∈X﻿ is

Voroni diagram of XXX﻿ is the set of XXX﻿’s Voroni cells

Size(# of vertices)∈O(n⌈d/2⌉)\text{Size(\# of vertices)} \in O(n^{\lceil d/2 \rceil})Size(# of vertices)∈O(n⌈d/2⌉)﻿

2D ⇒ O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn)﻿ time to compute the digram and a trapezoidal map for point location, O(logn)O(logn)O(logn)﻿ query time

dD ⇒ Use binary space partition tree (BSP tree) for point location

k-d Trees

Build:

Very similar to decision trees, differences:

  1. Chooses splitting feature with greatest width ⇒ choose feature iii﻿ ⇒ arg max⁡i(Xji−Xki)\argmax_{i} (X_{ji} - X_{ki})argmaxi​(Xji​−Xki​)﻿
    1. We want the cutted box to be as closely to cubical as possible
    1. Or we can instead rotate the features, builds the tree faster by a factor of O(d)O(d)O(d)﻿
  1. Choose splitting value ⇒ median point for feature i
    1. Guarentees ⌊log⁡2n⌋\lfloor \log_2 n \rfloor⌊log2​n⌋﻿ tree depth
  1. Each internal node stores a sample point ⇒ usually its the splitting point

Build time: O(ndlog⁡n)O(nd \log n)O(ndlogn)﻿, or O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn)﻿ if we rotate through the features

Query:

ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿ ⇒ parameter for approximate NN ⇒ in high dimensional space its likely to have several points equidistant from the query point, approximate NN saves tons of time

AdaBoost

👆Check out the video above, very useful

Idea: We will train TTT﻿ classifiers(weak learners), G1,…,GTG_1, \dots, G_TG1​,…,GT​﻿, and combine them into a big metalearner M(z)M(z)M(z)﻿

Each weak learner will get a different “amount of say” βt\beta_tβt​﻿ by how much error they made during training.

Risk Function:

(Exponential) Loss Function:

With this loss, we will pick GTG_TGT​﻿ that minimizes the sum of sample weights over all misclassified points!

Sample Weights: (Initialize each weight with 1n\frac{1}{n}n1​﻿)

Amount of say: (Equation obtained by setting derivative of risk to 0)

Where
